results.content: Good course. Vasco is one of my go-to instructors on Udemy. He's knowledgeable and thorough. The code needs to be brought up to date; some of it is a little dated as of early 2021. The course uses the v10 LTS version of node, so if you (likely) have something newer it's a setup headache unless you have nvm. I wish there were completed versions of the lessons available also. The transcript is only in Spanish, which is annoying when you reach for it only to be reminded that you can't read it. Overall, still a recommended course as an solid introduction to this topic.
results.content_html: Good course. Vasco is one of my go-to instructors on Udemy. He's knowledgeable and thorough. The code needs to be brought up to date; some of it is a little dated as of early 2021. The course uses the v10 LTS version of node, so if you (likely) have something newer it's a setup headache unless you have nvm. I wish there were completed versions of the lessons available also. The transcript is only in Spanish, which is annoying when you reach for it only to be reminded that you can't read it. Overall, still a recommended course as an solid introduction to this topic.

results.content: The title of this course is misleading. It's not really about Angular or frontend-specific security but about security in web development in general (as is also admitted in the very last video). An estimated half of the course is about the backend and not about Angular. I missed out on XSS attacks and CSP. Issues such as dealing with third party components and their vulnerabilities were also not addressed.
results.content_html: The title of this course is misleading. It's not really about Angular or frontend-specific security but about security in web development in general (as is also admitted in the very last video). An estimated half of the course is about the backend and not about Angular. I missed out on XSS attacks and CSP. Issues such as dealing with third party components and their vulnerabilities were also not addressed.

results.content:
I have multiple course purchased from you.

Things that I loved:
- Focused on the subject, without distracting things
- Separate files for different things ( clean, but you will see a CON about it below)
 
Personally I did not like the following:
- Why would you keep switching from branch to branch? What are the main differences between them? You couldn't go with 1 branch and explain what we need to do for that and that?
- Some videos where you copy/paste code, I prefer to follow you typing it
- I know you write clean code, but you should refactor the back-end / server code in folders, is so dirty with all those files, sometimes I need to open  2 or 3 to get the right one.

results.content:
Changing from lesson to lesson sometimes leaves out explanation (especially when moving from branch to branch) of how/why some code was added. Like importing modules that were used.

Verbal delivery move so quickly that it is hard to digest what is said, especially with the speaker's accent.  The speaker needs to slow down so that the user can take in the lesson.  Editing is sometimes choppy.

In all, I would recommend the course as one of the best security course.

results.content:
In Section 6 the course combined the Resource Server with Authorization Server functionality. 

In Section 8, rightly so, authentication was delegated to an Authorization Service (Auth0).

However, in section 9, all the security related aspects of an Authorization Server were brought back into the Resource Server realm. I don't fully understand the motivation to go back and forth.

If it was decided to use Auth0 for delegating authorization work then why not use Auth0 for both Access and Identity Tokens and use scopes and claims support available in Auth0 ? 

Since I could not install the source code (I have a ticket open), I spent the time reading about Auth0 and found that a good coverage of Auth0's scopes and claims in this course would have gone a long way to help solidify concepts. Section 9 on RBAC seemed regressive after the author spoke so much in Section 7 and 8 about not introducing security implementation in our Resource Servers and then later fully integrating it in Section 9.

The course started out brilliantly but leaves out important pieces and creates confusion in the latter sections.

response.content: Hello Rahul, the goal is to present the authorization concepts independently of Auth0, so that is why we are using a custom implementation where we do things from scratch.  Without those concepts, we wont be able to use third-party solutions like Auth0.
response.content_html: Hello Rahul, the goal is to present the authorization concepts independently of Auth0, so that is why we are using a custom implementation where we do things from scratch. Without those concepts, we wont be able to use third-party solutions like Auth0.

results.content_html:
In Section 6 the course combined the Resource Server with Authorization Server functionality.

In Section 8, rightly so, authentication was delegated to an Authorization Service (Auth0).

However, in section 9, all the security related aspects of an Authorization Server were brought back into the Resource Server realm. I don't fully understand the motivation to go back and forth.

If it was decided to use Auth0 for delegating authorization work then why not use Auth0 for both Access and Identity Tokens and use scopes and claims support available in Auth0 ?

Since I could not install the source code (I have a ticket open), I spent the time reading about Auth0 and found that a good coverage of Auth0's scopes and claims in this course would have gone a long way to help solidify concepts. Section 9 on RBAC seemed regressive after the author spoke so much in Section 7 and 8 about not introducing security implementation in our Resource Servers and then later fully integrating it in Section 9.

The course started out brilliantly but leaves out important pieces and creates confusion in the latter sections.

results.content: Good introduction to using security in an Angular context. Really enjoyed the demonstration and introduction to using JWT and RBAC authentication. The course is well presented and is broken down into very manageable modules of roughly 5-10 minutes each; this makes it a lot easier to catchup with any code issues encountered during the lessons. Especially impressive was the availability of Git projects per module! Simply do a Git checkout and you're ready to code along. Very much appreciated that
results.content_html: Good introduction to using security in an Angular context. Really enjoyed the demonstration and introduction to using JWT and RBAC authentication. The course is well presented and is broken down into very manageable modules of roughly 5-10 minutes each; this makes it a lot easier to catchup with any code issues encountered during the lessons. Especially impressive was the availability of Git projects per module! Simply do a Git checkout and you're ready to code along. Very much appreciated that

Excellent presentation / teaching skills as always.

results.content: "Angular 6 Security Masterclass" - sorry, but this title is a clickbait... I really appreciate that the author had cover security issues with a real world examples and deep explanations, but maybe 20% of this course is about Angular ... Server - side implemented with NodeJS is much more covered than frontend ! I've learned a lot more from other courses, which were not cencerned about security than from this "Masterclass" . I'm dissapointed

response.content:
Hello Aleksander, sorry to disappoint you, the majority of the code written is actually for the frontend.  It's not possible to explain how to secure an application by covering only the frontend, showing what to do in the backend is essential as well.  

Without the backend, its impossible to secure an application, so the course would not make sense without covering the backend, which we did here in Node / Typescript.
response.content_html:
Hello Aleksander, sorry to disappoint you, the majority of the code written is actually for the frontend. It's not possible to explain how to secure an application by covering only the frontend, showing what to do in the backend is essential as well.

Without the backend, its impossible to secure an application, so the course would not make sense without covering the backend, which we did here in Node / Typescript.

results.content_html: "Angular 6 Security Masterclass" - sorry, but this title is a clickbait... I really appreciate that the author had cover security issues with a real world examples and deep explanations, but maybe 20% of this course is about Angular ... Server - side implemented with NodeJS is much more covered than frontend ! I've learned a lot more from other courses, which were not cencerned about security than from this "Masterclass" . I'm dissapointed

results.content: Fantastic course! I dont recommend you use Windows though, participants should use linux if they want to avoid headaches...

results.content:
It's a good course but some parts are outdated. 
I had problems with npm install, because argon2 package was causing errors. I've updated that package to the newest version and the errors were fixed. The auth0 section is outdated, because the methods used and packages are different now. RxJs operators are also outdated (now we use pipe). 
Overall, the information provided is helpful but the course needs to be updated.
results.content_html:
It's a good course but some parts are outdated.

Overall, the information provided is helpful but the course needs to be updated.
